&applet; Manual
The &applet; shows the active keyboard group and enables switching between different groups.

This manual describes version &appletversion; of the &applet; applet.
Feedback
To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the &applet; applet or this manual, follow the directions in the MATE Feedback Page.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &applet; indicates the active keyboard group. The applet shows you which group you are currently using. Aside from the standard applet popup menu functions, the &applet; applet popup menu allows you to launch the applet Preferences tool and to switch between language groups.
To add &applet; to a panel, right-click on the panel, then choose Add to Panel. Select &applet; in the Add to the panel dialog, then click OK. For more on this, see Adding an Object to a Panel.

To open the Keyboard preference tool, choose Open Keyboard Preferences in the applet popup menu. You may need to go to this dialog to be able to configure the keyboard (choose model, layouts, options, etc.). For help with setting Keyboard preferences, see Configuring Keyboard Preferences.

sect1.title: Switching Language
sect1.para: First, you must know that a group is a set of characters, whether it be for a language or non-language-related set of characters, like a dvorak. Each language may have more than one subset, and each subset is called a group. There are many ways you can switch the group that you are using on your keyboard.

listitem.para: You can switch between groups with a single click on the applet's panel icon. The groups switch in a cycle determined by the current configuration.
To pick a specific group, select Groups from the popup menu. From there, choose the group you want to switch to.

In the Keyboard preference tool, you can set which key that you would like to use to switch groups on your keyboard. Choose Open Keyboard Preferences in the applet popup menu, and choose the key you want to use in the Layout Options tab, under Group Shift/Lock behavior.

sect1.para: To add other layouts to the list, open the Keyboard preference tool. Choose other layouts in the Layouts tab.

sect1.title: Layout View
sect1.para: Choose Layout View from the applet popup menu to see a diagram of your current keyboard layout.
In the Layout View window, press a key on your keyboard to highlight its representation in the diagram.
Each key in the diagram has up to four characters. These can be produced with different keyboard modifiers, as follows:

listitem.para: For the character shown in the bottom left, press the key alone.
For the character shown in the top left, press the key with Shift.
For the character shown in the bottom right, press the key with the third level modifier.
For the character shown in the top right, press the key with Shift and the third level modifier.

note.para: By default, no key is assigned to act as a third-level modifier. You can assign a key to act as a third level modifier in the Keyboard Layout Options Preferences.

sect1.title: Plugins
sect1.para: To open the Keyboard Indicator Plugins dialog, select Plugins from the popup menu. Your current plugins are shown in the Active plugins area.

listitem.para: Click Add. In the Add Plugin window, select one of the plugins in the Available plugins area and click the OK button.
Select the plugin in the Active plugins area that you do not want anymore and click Remove.

varlistentry.term: Moving Items in the Plugin List

listitem.para: To move items up and down the plugin list in the Active plugins area, select the plugin you want to move, and click Up or Down. You can use the arrows on the keyboard to move the selection point up and down.

varlistentry.term: Changing the Properties of a Plugin

listitem.para: To change the properties of the plugins, select the plugin you want and click Properties. The properties vary for each plugin.
